awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Venturi Vacuum Device for Biological and Particulate Sample Collection
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to improve the capabilities of sample collection in industries where this step is critical to high quality results. Currently, poor recovery efficiencies, inability to collect from diverse environments, and no standardization affects this activity. The proposed technology will improve sample collection systems for better ease of sampling, an improved range of samples that can be collected, and the quality of evidence collected for the forensic science industry, expected to be a ~$40 B industry by 2025.  The solution would lead to less failed testing, improved utilization of time and resources, and improved case-solving opportunities. 

This I-Corps project will explore a venturi-based technology to generate a vacuum. Through a modular design, many front-end applicators can be equipped to allow one handheld device to collect a number of samples. The device is lightweight, portable, field deployable and requires no electricity. It uses a compressed air tank to power the venturi pump. This device can collect trace amounts of “touch-DNA” evidence, particulates from solid and porous surfaces, and pathogens associated with agricultural disease in infected trees. This technology will allow experts to collect more efficiently samples and enable new sample collection and testing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Forensic evidence such as touch DNA samples, organic or inorganic particulates, and other trace evidence are often encountered at crime scenes. Trace sample collection can be challenging, especially if the evidence is found in difficult to access areas such as cracks, under wall moldings, on rough surfaces. Latent fingerprints also leave cellular material behind but produce low DNA yield. Therefore, often a decision has to be made whether to recover the DNA from an object or a fingerprint. Many security-related samples encountered in counterterrorism are also found at trace levels--gunshot residue, explosives, and drugs. ICORPs GOAL: There is a strong need to overcome and improve the collection and recovery capabilities of trace evidence, especially cellular debris and DNA, leading to an important advance in providing improved analytical testing capabilities downstream that will pass rigor in courts. The purpose of the ICORPs is to 'get out of the building', interview the end users and gain awareness into how to solve some of the problems they may encounter. This provides critical information as to whether or not your novel method will improve the evidence collection. Interviews that were conducted gave insight into the challenges of: (a) collection of touch evidence samples, (b) current collection methods used and why they use them, and most importantly (c) even if one can improve collection with a novel device, overcoming acceptance, procurement and integration into crime lab workflows will be difficult, but not impossible, to overcome.

 

"Getting out of the building" entailed conducting 120 interviews in 5 weeks to learn where the "pain points" of evidence collection were in the forensic workflow. The caveat to the interviews was to listen, ask questions, learn, but not discuss our collection device-- the Venturi Vacuum Device (VVD), US patent # 10,908,05-- that we perceived as a device that would improve efficiency of collection of many classes of evidence. Lessons learned: In many of the smaller forensic units, collection was based on the cheapest device they could purchase under constrained budgets--the cotton swab. They recognized that this was far from efficient, but swabs are widely accepted in the forensic community as a collection method and it was all their budgets allowed them to purchase.  The larger units had less budget constraints but in most crime units, in order to adopt a new device or method, it has to be internally validated, thus they are very slow to change as it takes many hours of personnel time to perform internal validations. In addition to validations, any new device has to be integrated into their procurement system as well as the workflow within the analytical laboratories. Overcoming this would be a hurdle but not an impossible one to do.

 

The basis of our novel device--the Venturi Vacuum Device (VVD)--was to be able to collect more sample using a vacuum and suction to recover and release from the matrix, additional cells or particulates that may otherwise not be collected (Figure 1). At conception, we modified a sterile syringe and attached a Venturi device, driven by compressed gas, to the syringe and had several front end devices we could attach to the syringe. It could use a needle to get into crevices or it could be fitted with different collection matrices attached to the suction cup. The second prototype, 3D printed, offered flatter surface, therefore, increasing the surface area of the collection zone. From one of the interviews, it was suggested to be able to pack the cylinder with glass wool to capture trace particulates in the matrix, recover the matrix and then wash with the appropriate solvent to recover and analyze.

Intellectual merit: The goal of the ICORPs--integrating in-person interviews, listening, and business analyses-- provided evidence from the potential end users as to the feasibility and viability of commercialization of your invention. This approach was new to most of the cohort's research scientists where the normal sequence of events are: write a proposal, procure funding, perform the research, publish their findings and move on to the next research project. What the ICORPs provided was an experiential awakening to think "beyond the bench" and deeply assess the impact on society your research could have. Broader Impact: Based on the ICORP experience, we were funded by the National Institute of Justice to compare the device to the traditional cotton swabs by sampling rough and porous surfaces. This funded two minority graduate students. The post doc was hired as a research assistant professor and continues to meet with industry partners to write a SBIR or a PFI proposal for commercialization.  ICORPs provided the travel funding but more importantly the training and insight to reevaluate the societal impact research findings can have on industry and ultimately, the public.

 


Last Modified: 08/13/2023
Modified by: Deetta K Mills

Image
  • Prototypes of the Venturi Vacuum Device (US Patent # 10,908,05) for the collection of forensic evidence.
    Dr. Julian Mendel
    Public Domain
